title: 106_s226
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999". It includes findings and a declaration of policy. The Act "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999" includes findings by Congress regarding the negative impact of successive military regimes in Nigeria, the progress made by the current regime under Gen. Abdusalami Abubakar, and the cooperation in halting international drug trafficking. Since 1993, the United States and other international members have imposed sanctions against Nigeria for human rights violations and political repression, some of which have been lifted due to recent political liberalization. Despite progress in protecting freedoms, decrees still exist that suspend constitutional rights, allow indefinite detention without charge, and revoke civilian court jurisdiction over executive actions. Nigeria is obligated to conduct fair elections under international agreements. Nigeria, as a leading military force in ECOWAS, has played a significant role in peacekeeping efforts in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Despite progress, recent events in the Niger Delta highlight the need for ongoing monitoring to prevent a return to repressive tactics. The United States aims to support Nigeria's transition to democratic governance through political, economic, and legal reforms to uphold the rule of law and human rights. The sense of Congress is for the President to coordinate with other countries to promote the rule of law, human rights, and democratic civilian government. The President should instruct the US Representative to the UN Human Rights Commission to condemn human rights abuses in Nigeria and advocate for the renewal of the special rapporteur's mandate. Assistance is provided to promote democracy and civil society in Nigeria. Development Assistance for Nigeria should include not less than $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, and $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 to promote democracy, good governance, and the rule of law through nongovernmental organizations representing a broad cross-section of Nigerian society. The United States Agency for International Development will provide grants to nongovernmental organizations in Nigeria to promote democracy, human rights, and accountable government. Additionally, the United States Information Agency will support activities in Nigeria to increase awareness. The United States Agency for International Development will increase staff levels in Nigeria to support activities promoting democracy, human rights, and accountable government. Congress finds current staff levels in Lagos inadequate and urges the Administrator to consider placing personnel elsewhere in Nigeria. Prohibition on economic and military assistance to Nigeria, requirement to oppose multilateral assistance for Nigeria. Prohibition on economic assistance to the Government of Nigeria, excluding disaster relief, refugee assistance, and narcotics control assistance. Prohibition on military assistance or arms transfers to Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for military assistance. Military assistance or arms transfers refer to assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 related to military assistance and international military education and training. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 prohibits military assistance or arms transfers to Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for such purposes. The Secretary of the Treasury must oppose any assistance to the Government of Nigeria from international financial institutions. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 prohibits military assistance or arms transfers to Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for such purposes. The Secretary of the Treasury must oppose any assistance to the Government of Nigeria from international financial institutions such as the African Development Bank, International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, International Development Association, International Finance Corporation, Multilateral Investment Guaranty Agency, and International Monetary Fund. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 prohibits military assistance or arms transfers to Nigeria. Congress urges the denial of visas to senior Nigerian government officials and military officers unless a democratic transition occurs. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for Nigeria if certain conditions are met, including respecting human rights and releasing political prisoners. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for Nigeria if certain conditions are met, including respecting human rights, repealing laws granting undue powers to the military, and ensuring policing in oil-producing communities is carried out without excessive force or human rights violations. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for Nigeria if certain conditions are met, including respecting human rights, repealing laws granting undue powers to the military, and ensuring policing in oil-producing communities is carried out without excessive force or human rights violations. Congressional notification is required at least 15 days in advance of any waiver. The Secretary of State must report on corruption in Nigeria every year for 5 years, including evidence of corruption by government officials, impact on government services, US business interests, advance fee fraud impact on US citizens, and impact on Nigeria's foreign policy. The term "appropriate congressional committees" in the Act refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The Act will terminate on September 30, 2004.
